ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Some Old English reading skills gained, though for the most part we were provided with translations. I learned to think deeper about the relationship between poetry and music and how each element complements/detracts from the other.

I was first introduced to Middle English, and after this course, I feel so much more comfortable with approaching Middle English writing. Greater context on the Middle Ages is also provided, specifically with information about scribes, manuscript formation, and religious background to lyrics. We spent a lot of time going through impact of word choice and sound, word placement, the nature of lyric, the implications behind the existence of written music with a given piece from the period, and more.
Learned more about the intersection between text/object/image and about medieval culture.
I really learned how to read and understand Middle English. Professor Butterfield is a wonder.

An understanding of European medieval poetic and musical styles, and an appreciation for medieval art more generally. I gained relative fluency in reading Middle English, and deciphering handwritten script.
I learned so much about medieval art and history as well as music.
I learned a lot about medieval lyric and how writing was crafted in those times. I learned how to decipher a much older version of English

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Essay criteria could be more clear. I felt confused as to what would constitute a strong paper. Seminar could have been structured to increase student engagement.
Prof Butterfield was so kind and sweet! Loved her.
I dont know if I have a strength/weakness breakdown but it seems like a class whose quality is dependent on the group to a higher degree than other seminars.

Strength is that you develop a genuine appreciation and understanding of medieval poetry. Weakness is analysis was kind of all over the place and not very much guiding theory or concrete answers, we modify just approached the text from our modern perspective guessing at what the original authors could have meant.

strength: very good overview of the genre, supplementary materials facilitated learning 
weakness: we maybe needed more pointers on how to read medieval texts at the beginning, since it's so different from modern English

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I did not love the material and was taking it as a requirement. I think people who were excited about the material had a good experience.

This is a great way to do the medieval requirement. You learn a lot but you also have a lot of freedom to explore the elements of the course that interest you, since the paper and project are both very open-ended.

This was an unexpectedly fun way to accomplish the medieval requirement for the English major, as no one knew what we were doing but laughed awkwardly together until we ended up becoming comfortable with Middle English and engaged with the poetry. Reading load wasnt too heavy, especially since we re-reviewed most of it slowly together in class. Ardis was an absolute delight, very kind and enthusiastic and encouraging. Wasnt super organized and couldnt tell you exactly what I learned though.
Yes if they are interested in a different sort of English class, where the texts feel like a puzzle that need to be deciphered.

Absolutely take this class!! Ardis is a wonderful professor and she facilitates a fun and engaging discussion every time. You can go into this course knowing nothing about the subject matter and it will still be fun and accessible. In my opinion, it's a really great choice for english majors who are looking to fill their medieval requirement. I didn't know what to expect from this class but it was a lot of fun and I strongly recommend it.
